Summary: Aid workers: Violence, increased cost of living drive women to prostitution. Group is working to raise awareness of the problem with Iraq's political leaders. Two Iraqi mothers tell CNN they turned to prostitution to help feed their children. "Everything is for the children," one woman says. Article: Aid workers in Iraq are reporting a disturbing trend of increased prostitution among women, as violence and the rising cost of living have left many mothers with no other options to feed their children. A group of workers is now trying to bring attention to the problem by urging Iraq’s political leaders to take action.

This issue was brought to light when two Iraqi mothers recently spoke to CNN about their experiences. Both mothers relayed how they had turned to prostitution in order to provide for their children. "Everything is for the children," one of the women explained.

Aid workers say that the economic struggles plaguing the country, coupled with ongoing violence, have created a dire situation in which many women feel they have no other choice. The issue is especially pressing for single mothers or those whose husbands have been killed or kidnapped.

The aid workers are hoping that by raising awareness of the problem, they can push for policies that will better support struggling families. They have called on political leaders to take action to address the root causes of the issue, including the cost of living and the ongoing violence.

Iraq's government has not yet responded to the calls of the aid workers, but they hope that their efforts will lead to meaningful change. For now, the stories of these mothers serve as a stark reminder of the devastating toll that poverty and violence can take on families.

Summary: Tomas Medina Caracas was a fugitive from a U.S. drug trafficking indictment. "El Negro Acacio" allegedly helped manage extensive cocaine network. U.S. Justice Department indicted him in 2002. Colombian military: He was killed in an attack on a guerrilla encampment. Article: Tomas Medina Caracas, also known as "El Negro Acacio", a fugitive from a U.S. drug trafficking indictment, has been reportedly killed in a guerrilla attack. According to Colombian military, Medina Caracas was involved in managing an extensive cocaine network. The U.S. Justice Department had indicted him in 2002, and he had been on the run since then.

The guerrilla attack took place on an encampment where Medina Caracas was allegedly staying. The Colombian military stated that several other guerrillas were also killed in the attack. The details about the attack and the extent of the damage caused are still unclear.

Medina Caracas was one of the most wanted drug traffickers in the world, and his cartel was known to have connections to various criminal organizations in South America and beyond. He had been on the run for almost two decades and was considered to be a significant threat to the U.S. government's efforts to curb drug trafficking.

The news of his death has been received with mixed reactions from different quarters. While some have welcomed it as a victory in the fight against drug trafficking, others have raised concerns about the effectiveness of militarized approaches to addressing the problem.

The U.S. government has not released an official statement regarding the incident. It remains to be seen whether this development will have any impact on the overall drug trafficking scenario in the region.

Summary: President Bush says Tony Snow "will battle cancer and win" Job of press secretary "has been a dream for me," Snow says Snow leaving on September 14, will be succeeded by Dana Perino. Article: Former President George W. Bush has offered words of encouragement to his former press secretary, Tony Snow, as the latter battles cancer. Speaking to reporters after a press conference, Bush praised Snow as a fighter, adding that he was confident his former aide would emerge victorious in his fight against cancer.

Meanwhile, Snow himself, who previously battled colon cancer before being diagnosed with a recurrence earlier this year, said that the job of press secretary had been a dream come true for him. In a statement he released earlier, Snow said he was "humbled and grateful for the opportunity" to serve as press secretary.

Snow went on to announce that he would be stepping down from his post on September 14, and would be succeeded by his deputy, Dana Perino. Snow praised Perino as a "brilliant colleague," adding that he was confident she would do an outstanding job.

Perino for her part said she was "honored and excited" to be taking over from Snow. She said she hoped to continue the good work he had done, and would strive to maintain the high standards of integrity and professionalism that had become the hallmark of the White House press office under Snow's leadership.

Summary: Empty anti-tank weapon turns up in front of New Jersey home. Device handed over to Army ordnance disposal unit. Weapon not capable of being reloaded, experts say. Article: Residents of a New Jersey neighborhood were left baffled when a seemingly empty anti-tank weapon turned up in front of a home on Monday. The device prompted concern among local law enforcement officials and residents alike, who were unsure of what the weapon was or how it got there. 

After the police were called, the Army's ordnance disposal unit was contacted to safely handle the situation. Shortly after, the device was taken away for proper disposal. The weapon was not capable of being reloaded, as experts confirmed, and was most likely a deactivated model that was used for training purposes. 

According to a spokesperson for the Army, the weapon was most likely discarded improperly and somehow found its way onto the residential streets. While it posed little danger to the public, the Army advises individuals to seek out proper channels for weapons disposal in order to avoid complications like this in the future. 

The discovery of the weapon has left some residents feeling uneasy. "This is a quiet neighborhood, you don't see anything like this around here", said one local resident. "I certainly hope this is a one-time occurrence and that something like this won't happen again." 

Fortunately, the authorities were able to professionally handle the situation, and residents are now able to breathe a sigh of relief knowing that any potential danger has been removed from their streets.

Summary: President Bush to address the Veterans of Foreign Wars on Wednesday. Bush to say that withdrawing from Vietnam emboldened today's terrorists. Speech will be latest White House attempt to try to reframe the debate over Iraq. Article: President George W. Bush is set to address the Veterans of Foreign Wars on Wednesday in Kansas City. The main topic of his speech will be the latest White House attempt to reframe the debate over Iraq. The President is expected to argue that withdrawing from Vietnam emboldened today's terrorists. 

This statement is likely to be a highly controversial one and will spark heated debate in the coming days. President Bush has previously spoken about the threat posed by ISIS and has frequently called for increased military action against them. 

The President has been under immense pressure in recent months as he strives to convince Americans that the war in Iraq is necessary. Many people are opposed to American involvement in the war, arguing that it is expensive and costing too many lives.

It remains to be seen how Bush's speech will be received by both the Veterans of Foreign Wars, as well as the wider American public. However, one thing is certain, it will continue to keep the debate surrounding Iraq well and truly alive.

Summary: Two cars loaded with gasoline and nails found abandoned in London Friday. 52 people killed on July 7, 2005 after bombs exploded on London bus, trains. British capital wracked by violence by the IRA for years. Article: London authorities had a close call on Friday when two cars loaded with gasoline and nails were found abandoned in the city. The discovery of the potentially deadly vehicles is a sobering reminder of the increased threat of terrorism that has plagued the British capital in recent years.

Friday's discovery comes just over a decade after the deadly terrorist attacks that rocked London on July 7, 2005. That day, 52 people were killed and hundreds more were injured when bombs exploded on a bus and several trains during rush hour. The heinous attacks were carried out by a group of Islamist militants with ties to al-Qaeda.

However, London's history of violence is not limited to extremist groups. For years, the Irish Republican Army (IRA) carried out a campaign of terror in the city, targeting both civilians and government institutions. The violence finally came to an end with the Good Friday Agreement in 1998.

It is unclear at this time who is responsible for the abandoned cars found on Friday. But the incident serves as a stark reminder of the ongoing risk of terrorism in London and the vigilance required to keep the city safe.

Summary: Werder Bremen pay a club record $10.7 million for Carlos Alberto. The Brazilian midfielder won the Champions League with FC Porto in 2004. Since January he has been on loan with his first club, Fluminense. Article: German soccer club Werder Bremen have broken their transfer record by paying $10.7 million to secure the services of Brazilian midfielder Carlos Alberto. Alberto, who won the Champions League with FC Porto in 2004, has been on loan with his first club, Fluminense, since January.

Werder Bremen hope that Alberto's experience and talent will help them improve on last season's disappointing seventh-place finish in the Bundesliga. "We see him as a key addition to our midfield and are excited to have him join us," said Bremen's sporting director Frank Baumann.

Alberto began his career at Fluminense before moving to Europe, where he played for several clubs including Porto, Corinthians and Werder's Bundesliga rivals, Werder Leverkusen. His recent loan spell back at Fluminense has seen him rediscover his best form, leading to interest from clubs across Europe.

Werder Bremen were able to seal the deal for the 27-year-old despite interest from several other clubs, thanks to the financial backing of their billionaire owner, Klaus Allofs. The club hope that Alberto will make an immediate impact when the new season kicks off in August.

Summary: President Bush will have a routine colonoscopy Saturday. While he's anesthetized, his powers will be transferred to the vice president. Bush had last colonoscopy in 2002, which found no problems. Article: Washington D.C. - President George W. Bush is scheduled to undergo a routine colonoscopy this Saturday at Camp David. As a precaution, his presidential powers will temporarily be transferred to Vice President Dick Cheney while he is anesthetized. 

This is not the first time the President has undergone this procedure. In fact, his last colonoscopy was back in 2002 and no complications were found. However, given the importance of presidential duties, it is standard procedure to have a standby President in place while the sitting President undergoes any medical procedures.

While it is expected to be a routine procedure, the topic of presidential health has been in the headlines in recent years. President Bush's father, George H.W. Bush, disclosed in 2012 that he had been diagnosed with vascular Parkinsonism, and in 2015, former President Jimmy Carter announced he had been diagnosed with melanoma that had spread to his brain.

Despite the potential risks, the White House has emphasized that President Bush is in good health and this is merely a preventative measure.

"This is a routine procedure and we don't anticipate any issues," said White House Press Secretary Dana Perino. "The President is in good health and the Vice President is prepared to step in if necessary."

The transfer of power is expected to be brief, with President Bush expected to be wake up and resume his duties shortly after the procedure.

Summary: President Bush says he and first lady are deeply saddened by the tragedy. Mine Safety and Health Administration chief: We've run out of options. The six men have been trapped underground since August 6. Seven bore holes drilled into the mountain have found no signs of life. Article: President George W. Bush issued a statement today expressing deep sadness over the tragedy of six miners who have been trapped underground in Utah since August 6th. Despite the efforts of rescue workers, the miners remain trapped and there are no signs of life.

The Mine Safety and Health Administration reports that they have run out of options in the rescue effort. Several bore holes have been drilled into the mountain to try and locate the stranded miners, but to no avail.

"Our hearts go out to the families and loved ones of the miners who remain trapped underground," said President Bush in a statement. "We commend the bravery and commitment of the rescue workers who have been working tirelessly to reach them."

The trapped miners, identified as Kerry Allred, Don Erickson, Luis Hernandez, Carlos Payan, Brandon Phillips and Manuel Sanchez, have been the subject of a nationwide rescue effort since the day they were trapped.

The tragedy has gripped the nation and offers of support and condolences have been pouring in from all across the country.

"Our thoughts and prayers are with the families of these miners during this trying time," said President Bush. "We will continue to work tirelessly to rescue them and bring them home safely."

Summary: Bomb victims waiting for presidential visit. Blast went off 15 minutes before president's arrival. Algeria faces Islamic insurgency. Al Qaeda-affiliated group claimed July attacks. Article: Algiers, Algeria - The victims of a recent bomb attack in the capital city of Algiers are waiting for a visit from President Abdelmadjid Tebboune. Unfortunately, 15 minutes before his scheduled arrival, another bomb went off in the area, likely intended for the president's convoy.

The blast occurred in the neighborhood of Bab Ezzouar, where two people were injured. Fortunately, no one was killed.

The country of Algeria is currently facing an Islamic insurgency, with an Al Qaeda-affiliated group claiming responsibility for recent attacks in July. The group has been targeting government and military installations as well as civilians.

President Tebboune, who was elected last December, has vowed to take strong action against the militants. However, he himself has been the target of an assassination attempt, which took place in late 2019.

The people of Algeria are hoping for an end to the violence and for stability to return to the country. The president's visit to the bomb victims shows his commitment to addressing the issue and making progress towards a safe and secure Algeria.

Summary: Beckham has agreed to a five-year contract with Los Angeles Galaxy. New contract took effect July 1, 2007. Former English captain to meet press, unveil new shirt number Friday. CNN to look at Beckham as footballer, fashion icon and global phenomenon. Article: Los Angeles Galaxy fans are in for a treat as their star player, David Beckham, has agreed to a five-year contract with the club. The new deal took effect from July 1, 2007, and ensures that the former English captain will continue to strum his magic on the football field for the Galaxy.

To celebrate this milestone, Beckham himself will be meeting with the press to unveil his new shirt number on Friday. This is great news for Galaxy fans who will be eager to find out which number Beckham will be sporting during the remainder of the season.

Beckham has become a household name not only for his skills on the football field but also for his fashion sense and global appeal. He has been lauded as a footballer, fashion icon, and a global phenomenon, something that CNN plans to examine in a special segment.

Beckham has already had a significant impact on the popularity of major league soccer in the United States since he arrived in 2007. His arrival was met with massive media attention, and he has since become a prominent figure both on and off the field.

With his contract renewal, Los Angeles Galaxy fans can rest assured that they will continue to witness Beckham's brilliance in action for years to come.

Summary: Colony collapse disorder has killed millions of bees. Scientists suspect a virus may combine with other factors to collapse colonies. Disorder first cropped up in 2004, as bees were imported from Australia. $15 billion in U.S. crops each year dependent on bees for pollination. Article: Millions of bees have died due to colony collapse disorder, which has been plaguing the bee population since 2004. Scientists have been trying to get to the bottom of the problem and suspect that a virus may be one of the contributing factors. They believe that the virus, along with other factors, may be leading to the collapse of colonies. 

The disorder first emerged in 2004, when bees were being imported from Australia. Since then, it has spread across the United States, causing great concern in the agriculture industry. This is because $15 billion worth of U.S. crops are dependent on bees for pollination each year. Without bees, many crops would have to be pollinated by hand, which would be a labor-intensive and costly process for farmers. 

Scientists are working to identify the virus and other factors that may be contributing to colony collapse disorder. They are hoping that by understanding the root causes of the problem, they can work on developing solutions to combat it. In the meantime, beekeepers and farmers are doing what they can to protect their hives and ensure that their crops continue to receive the pollination they need to thrive. 

The impact of colony collapse disorder is far-reaching and could have serious consequences for food production if not addressed. It is clear that urgent action is needed to save these vital insects and protect our agricultural industry for years to come.

Summary: Savers at leading UK mortgage bank lined up to empty their accounts. Northern Rock was bailed out by the Bank of England a day earlier. Reassurances that banks was safe have gone unheeded by many. Article: Savers at Northern Rock, the leading UK mortgage bank, were seen lining up to empty their accounts in the wake of the recent bailout by the Bank of England. Despite reassurances from officials that the bank was safe, many customers remained unnerved and withdrew their funds.

The Bank of England stepped in to save Northern Rock on September 14, 2007, after fears of a collapse in the mortgage market led to a loss of confidence from investors and a run on the bank. The move was an unusual one, as it marked the first bailout of a UK bank in over 30 years.

Despite the intervention by the Bank of England, many savers at Northern Rock remained anxious about the safety of their money, leading to long queues outside branches as customers rushed to withdraw their funds.

The bank's executives attempted to calm fears, with CEO Adam Applegarth appearing on television to assure customers that their money was safe. He said: "Our focus is on protecting our customers and their savings. We have a strong franchise, and we will come through this."

However, such reassurances were not enough to sway many customers. Reports suggest that as much as £2 billion ($2.6 billion) was withdrawn in the days following the bailout.

Overall, the incident sparked concerns about the wider financial system and led to a government review of financial regulation in the UK. It also marked a significant moment in the global financial crisis, which would continue to unfold in the years that followed.

Summary: No bail for ex-NFL star accused of directing men in alleged armed robbery. Simpson faces charges of robbery, assault, burglary and conspiracy. Alleged robbery involved sports-related items, police say. Simpson arrested Sunday in Las Vegas, but he says items were his. Article: Former NFL star O.J. Simpson appeared in court on Tuesday and was denied bail in relation to charges of robbery, assault, burglary, and conspiracy. The charges stem from an alleged armed robbery involving sports-related items, according to the police. Simpson was arrested in Las Vegas on Sunday.

During the hearing, prosecutors argued that Simpson was a flight risk and posed a danger to the community. According to reports, Simpson's defense lawyer argued that the items involved in the alleged robbery belonged to Simpson and that he was simply trying to retrieve his own property.

Simpson is best known for his football career, but also for his highly publicized trial in 1995 for the murders of his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ron Goldman. While he was acquitted of those charges, he has faced other legal troubles in the years since.

The current robbery charges against Simpson carry the possibility of a lengthy prison sentence if he is convicted. The judge in the case set a preliminary hearing for Thursday, October 5th, at which time Simpson will be formally arraigned on the charges.

Summary: Indictment: Man tried to pass nuclear filters to foreign agent. Roy Lynn Oakley appears in court in Tennessee after surrendering. Facility's role is to break down decommissioned equipment. Lawyer: Oakley's job was to break machine parts into pieces, pitch them. Article: A Tennessee man, Roy Lynn Oakley, has been indicted for attempting to supply nuclear filters to a foreign agent. Oakley surrendered himself and appeared in court on Monday. The facility where Oakley worked was responsible for breaking down decommissioned equipment. According to his lawyer, Oakley's job was to break machine parts into pieces to be pitched. The indictment indicates that Oakley was attempting to supply equipment that had not been decommissioned. 

This incident has raised concern over the security of nuclear equipment and the ease with which it can be supplied to foreign agents. Investigations are ongoing to determine if Oakley was working alone or if he had accomplices. Officials have stated that they will do everything possible to ensure that this kind of situation does not occur in the future. 

The dangers of nuclear proliferation are well known, and incidents like this are taken very seriously. The Tennessee authorities have pledged to work closely with the federal government to prevent such incidents from happening again. According to experts, nuclear filters are crucial components that can be used in a variety of nuclear applications, including the development of nuclear weapons. 

Oakley has been released on bail, and arrangements have been made to monitor his movements until his trial. The FBI and other agencies are still investigating the matter. The indictment alleges that Oakley attempted to provide classified information to a foreign agent. It remains to be seen how this case will be resolved. 

The incident has also raised questions about the recruitment process for sensitive jobs. Authorities will need to examine the vetting process to determine if anything needs to be changed to prevent a similar situation in the future. Overall, this case has highlighted the need for greater vigilance when it comes to the handling of nuclear equipment and the security of sensitive information.

Summary: Organ shortage in rich states has created a trade from poorer countries. "Transplant tourists" travel to poor countries to buy organs from the desperate. Pakistan, where trade in human organs is legal, is turning into a "kidney bazaar" Patients pay $8,500 for a new kidney, while donors are paid just $300 to $1,000. Article: Organ Shortage Driving Trade from Poorer Countries, Contributing to Global Health Crisis

As the number of people in need of organ transplants continues to rise in the world's wealthiest nations, so too does a disturbing trend: transplant tourism. Since the shortage of organs in rich states has created a trade from poorer countries, dubbed "kidney bazaars," desperate patients have been travelling to these areas to buy organs from willing donors.

One such country is Pakistan, where the trade in human organs is legal. As a result, the country is quickly becoming a hotspot for "transplant tourists" seeking out new kidneys, with patients paying upwards of $8,500 for the life-saving procedure. Meanwhile, donors are often paid a mere $300 to $1,000 for this invasive and risky operation.

The global organ shortage has contributed to a health crisis, as the number of patients who succumb to serious illnesses due to lack of access to organs continues to climb. According to the World Health Organization, around 10% of all transplants occur through the black market, though this figure is most likely much higher. High demand drives prices up, and people in poorer countries are more likely to be willing to take the risks involved - such as infection and permanent damage - in order to earn money quickly.

Many of these donors are unaware of the health risks involved, with some being deceived into believing they are simply undergoing a medical examination and not the actual transplant operation. Others, meanwhile, are sold into the trade by human traffickers.

The ethical implications of this trade are overwhelming. Those who are desperate for organs are still, after all, taking advantage of people in need. While the trade may be legal in some impoverished nations, it is often that little protection is provided for donors who may have been coerced into risking their life. And, the fact remains that the majority of those who sell their organs are impoverished and in need of immediate cash, which is why they take such a decision, putting their life on the line.

Yet, the global demand continues to soar whilst the supply remains stagnant. Meanwhile, it is poor individuals in poorer countries who bare the brunt of the crisis. Ultimately, should any such personal circumstances arise, it is therefore far more urgent to address the shortage of donated organs both locally and globally.

Summary: Because of troubles, Lindsay Lohan likely difficult to insure. Lohan supposed to appear in Shirley MacLaine film "Poor Things" Insurance rates may cost 1 to 3 percent of film's production budget. Article: Reports have emerged that troubled actress Lindsay Lohan is facing difficulties in finding insurance to cover her upcoming role in the Shirley MacLaine film "Poor Things". Insiders in the film industry suggest that Lohan's previous brushes with the law and substance abuse issues have made her a high-risk choice for insurance companies, with some estimates suggesting that insurance rates for her could cost anywhere from 1 to 3 percent of the film's entire production budget.

Lohan, who has had a rocky career marked by multiple stints in rehab, legal battles, and negative press attention, was set to join a star-studded cast in "Poor Things", including actresses Shirley MacLaine and Regina King. However, the latest reports have cast doubt on her participation in the project, as the filmmakers have yet to secure insurance coverage that would safeguard the film against any potential mishaps or delays during production.

Insiders in the film industry say that Lohan's troubles are not unique, and that other high-risk actors have faced similar challenges in the past. However, Lohan's struggles with addiction and legal issues have made her a particularly challenging case for insurers, and could result in her being deemed too much of a liability for the production company to take on.

At present, it remains unclear how Lohan's situation will ultimately play out, and whether or not she will be able to fulfill her role in "Poor Things". However, the insurance issues facing the production cast a shadow over what was already a challenging and high-stakes project, raising serious questions for the film industry as a whole about how best to handle the risks associated with working with unpredictable stars like Lohan.

Summary: Francesco Totti threatens to quit the Italian Players' Association. The Italy and Roma striker is upset over the early start to the new season. He says: We are the principal actors, but ... are never listened to." Article: Francesco Totti, the Italy and Roma striker, has threatened to quit the Italian Players' Association over the early start to the new season. Totti expressed his displeasure with the lack of input players have in scheduling and organizing games, stating that "We are the principal actors, but our opinions and our needs are never listened to."

Totti's outburst came as the start of the new Serie A season was brought forward to August 18th, putting pressure on players who have only just returned from their summer breaks. Totti sees this as part of a wider trend of players being asked to sacrifice too much for the sake of the game.

"The players are always the ones who suffer," he said. "We have to play every three days, we have no rest, no time with our families. The clubs and the associations don't care about us as people, they just want us to perform. It's not right."

Totti's words were met with a mixed reaction from other players in the association, with some supporting his stance and others feeling that his threat to quit was unnecessary. However, most agreed that players need to have a greater say in the way the football calendar is structured.

"Francesco has a point," said one unnamed player. "We need to be more vocal about our needs and our reasonable demands. But I don't think quitting the association is the answer. We need to work together to find a solution."

The Italian Players' Association has yet to respond to Totti's comments, but it is clear that his words have struck a chord with many players who feel that they are being stretched to their limits by the demands of the modern game. Whether or not Totti follows through on his threat to quit, the issue of player welfare is one that is unlikely to go away anytime soon.

Summary: Two employees bought, sold weapons on their own, company says. Company fired workers, turned them in to ATF, says source. Feds investigating claims Blackwater employees made illegal arms deals. Blackwater in spotlight after shootings last weekend that killed 20 Iraqis. Article: The controversial private military company, Blackwater, is once again under scrutiny after it was revealed that two of its former employees participated in illegal arms deals. According to a company source, the employees engaged in the buying and selling of weapons on their own, without the knowledge or authorization of Blackwater.

As soon as the company learned of the illegal activity, the employees were immediately terminated and reported to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF). The ATF is now investigating the claims of illegal arms dealing, which could result in criminal charges for the former Blackwater employees.

This latest scandal for Blackwater comes on top of last weekend’s tragic shootings in Iraq, where 20 Iraqis were killed. Blackwater has been widely criticized for its actions in Iraq and this new revelation reinforces concerns about the company’s operations.

The use of private military contractors has been a contentious issue throughout the Iraq War and Blackwater has been at the center of many controversies. Critics argue that the use of such companies undermines accountability and transparency in military operations.

As this new investigation unfolds, many will be watching to see if Blackwater is held accountable for the actions of its former employees and what, if any, further repercussions will result.

Summary: Boy on meeting Spider-Man: "It was my favorite thing" Youssif also met SpongeBob, Lassie and an orangutan at Universal Studios. Dad: "Other than my wedding day, this is the happiest day of my life" Article: A 7-year-old boy named Youssif recently had the experience of a lifetime when he met the iconic superhero Spider-Man at Universal Studios. Youssif, who was visiting the park with his family, couldn't contain his excitement as he shared his thoughts on the encounter.

"It was my favorite thing," Youssif said of meeting the web-slinging hero.

But Spider-Man was just one of several beloved characters that Youssif had the chance to meet that day. He also got to spend time with SpongeBob, Lassie, and even an orangutan.

For Youssif's dad, the day was just as memorable. "Other than my wedding day, this is the happiest day of my life," he shared.

The family's visit to Universal Studios was one that they will surely cherish for years to come. Youssif's thrill in meeting his favorite characters and his dad's happiness in seeing his son so joyful offer a reminder of the importance of creating unforgettable memories with loved ones.

Summary: Cpl. Trent D. Thomas found guilty this week of conspiracy to commit murder. Marine gets rank of private, will be discharged for role in death of Iraqi civilian. Group's leader awaits trial on murder and conspiracy charges. Article: Cpl. Trent D. Thomas has been found guilty of conspiracy to commit murder this week, marking a dark moment in the history of the U.S. Marine Corps. Thomas, who played a role in the death of an innocent Iraqi civilian, has been demoted to the rank of private and will be discharged from the Marine Corps. The verdict was handed down after weeks of trial proceedings.

Thomas was part of a group led by another Marine, who is currently awaiting trial on murder and conspiracy charges. The group was accused of targeting and killing an Iraqi man who was deemed a threat to their ongoing operations in the area. Thomas was found to have played a role in the conspiracy to target and kill the innocent man.

The verdict is a tragic reminder of the high price of war and the need for military personnel to adhere to strict ethical principles. The Marine Corps has made clear that any violation of these principles will not be tolerated, and that those who engage in unethical behavior will be held accountable.

For Thomas, the verdict marks the end of his military career and a solemn reminder of the responsibility that comes with serving one's country. The Marine Corps will continue to investigate the actions of all those involved in this tragic incident, with the goal of ensuring that justice is served and that similar incidents do not happen in the future.

The verdict has sent shockwaves through the military community, serving as a stark reminder of the need to maintain the highest standards of conduct and ethics, especially during times of war. The prosecution of Thomas and his co-conspirators sends a clear message that the Marine Corps will not tolerate any behavior that undermines the values and principles of the military.

Summary: Prince Harry describes Princess Diana as "the best mother in the world" He asks for her to be remembered as "fun-loving, generous, down-to-earth, entirely genuine" Bishop of London praises her humanitarian work. He says that disputes about her death should "end here" Article: Prince Harry paid a heartfelt tribute to his late mother, Princess Diana, during a ceremony at the Ribbon of Life Walk charity event in Hyde Park, London. The Prince described Princess Diana as "the best mother in the world" and asked for her to be remembered as "fun-loving, generous, down-to-earth, entirely genuine." 

The Duke of Sussex also expressed his appreciation for his mother’s philanthropy and humanitarian efforts, citing her dedication to social justice causes such as HIV/AIDS awareness and landmine disarmament. 

The Bishop of London, Right Reverend Sarah Mullally, also spoke at the event, praising Princess Diana for her humanitarian work and urging that any disputes about her death should "end here." Mullally also commended the efforts of the Ribbon of Life Walk organizers, who raise funds and awareness for HIV/AIDS charities.

The tribute to Princess Diana also included a walk through Hyde Park, which was lined with 100,000 ribbons in honor of those who have lost their lives to the HIV virus. Over 3,000 participants walked the route, raising an estimated £500,000 ($655,000) to support HIV/AIDS charities.

The event was a touching tribute to Princess Diana, who passed away over two decades ago in August 1997. Prince Harry’s heartfelt words and the Bishop of London’s message of reconciliation and remembrance reminded attendees of her enduring legacy as a caring mother and humanitarian.

Summary: French FM Kouchner has told France to prepare for possibility of war with Iran. Was a surprise appointment to Nicolas Sarkozy's conservative government. Also the first French Foreign Minister to visit Iraq since 1988. Founder of Medicins Sans Frontiers, also French student leader in May 1968. Article: French Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner has sent shockwaves throughout the nation after warning that France must prepare for the possibility of war with Iran. In a surprising move, Kouchner was appointed to Nicolas Sarkozy's conservative government, becoming the first French official to visit Iraq since 1988.

A respected figure in French politics, Kouchner is also known for founding the humanitarian organization Medicins Sans Frontiers and leading the French student protests of May 1968. However, it is his recent comments on Iran that have caused the most controversy.

Speaking to reporters, Kouchner stated that the world could not allow Iran to possess nuclear weapons and that all options, including military action, must be considered. "We have to prepare for the worst, and the worst is war," he said.

Kouchner's comments have been met with mixed reactions in France. Some politicians have praised his boldness, while others have criticized the rhetoric as too extreme. Many citizens are also expressing concerns about the potential fallout of a new conflict in the region.

Nonetheless, Kouchner has remained resolute in his beliefs. "We cannot simply sit back and hope for the best when it comes to Iran," he said. "We must be prepared to act decisively to protect our nation and our allies."

The situation in Iran continues to escalate, with recent reports suggesting that the country has made significant progress in developing its nuclear capabilities. As tensions rise, Kouchner's warnings may prove to be prophetic in the weeks and months ahead.

Summary: Several famous songs written by men for a woman. Beethoven's "Für Elise" may have been written "for Therese" Songwriters make up stories about who is behind "867-5309/Jenny" Article: In the world of music, there are plenty of songs that have been written about women, but sometimes those women remain a mystery. Some songs, however, are rumored to be written explicitly for one woman in particular.

One such example is Beethoven's famous piece "Für Elise." While the true identity of the woman behind the song is still up for debate, some experts believe that the song may have been written for a woman named Therese. Beethoven wrote several letters to a woman named Therese during his lifetime, so the theory holds some weight.

Another song with a mysterious woman at its center is "867-5309/Jenny" by Tommy Tutone. The song is famously catchy, but the true identity of Jenny remains a mystery. Songwriters have made up all sorts of stories about who Jenny might be, from a real-life love interest of lead singer Tommy Heath to a made-up character entirely.

Despite the mystery surrounding the women behind these songs, one thing is for sure: they've left a mark on music history. Whether it's the timeless charm of "Für Elise" or the catchy hook of "867-5309/Jenny," these songs will continue to be beloved by music fans for generations to come.

Summary: Amount almost double what was spent in 2004 election cycle. Lower TV production costs help more candidates advertise. Mitt Romney leads presidential candidates in TV spending. Advertisers face challenge of cutting through clutter of ads, analyst says. Article: As the race for the presidency heats up, candidates are spending big bucks to capture voters' attention. According to recent data, the amount spent on television advertising during this election cycle is almost double what was spent in 2004. However, lower production costs have allowed more candidates to advertise on television, meaning more competition for airtime. 

Leading the pack in TV spending is Mitt Romney, who has shelled out over $56 million. Other candidates, such as President Obama, have also spent heavily on television ads in an effort to sway undecided voters. 

However, advertisers are facing the challenge of cutting through the clutter of ads. With so many candidates vying for attention, it is becoming increasingly difficult to create a memorable advertisement. Analysis shows that candidates who create ads with a clear and simple message are more likely to be remembered by viewers. 

Despite the challenges, candidates continue to invest heavily in television advertising, recognizing its effectiveness in reaching a broad audience. As the election draws closer, it will be interesting to see which candidate's ad campaign will ultimately prove most successful in capturing voters' attention.

Summary: Relatives of the 89 people killed in Thai air crash are still arriving in Phuket. About 36 of the bodies have yet to be identified, according to Thai authorities. U.S. Embassy in Bangkok confirms that five Americans were among the dead. The investigation into what caused Sunday's crash is still continuing. Article: Phuket, Thailand - Grief-stricken relatives of the 89 people killed in Sunday's air crash in Thailand continue to arrive in the resort town of Phuket. According to Thai authorities, about 36 of the bodies have yet to be identified.

The fatal flight, operated by a Thai budget airline, crashed into a forested hillside while attempting to land in stormy weather. The exact cause of the crash is still unknown, but Thai officials have confirmed that five Americans were among the dead.

The U.S. Embassy in Bangkok released a statement expressing its condolences to the families of the victims, and offering assistance to those affected by the tragedy.

Search and rescue teams have been working around the clock since the crash, but have faced difficulties due to the remote location and difficult terrain. Officials have called in reinforcements, including a team of U.S. military personnel with experience in disaster response.

Meanwhile, the investigation into the cause of the crash is ongoing. Thailand's aviation department has already ruled out engine failure and pilot error, but other factors, including weather and technical issues are still being examined.

With so many families still waiting for news of their loved ones, the mood in Phuket remains somber. As rescue efforts continue and the investigation unfolds, the world mourns with the families of those lost in this tragic event.

Summary: Moore criticized a report Gupta did on CNN Monday on "Sicko" Gupta's report questions some of the movie's numbers and solutions. Gupta: "I thought it was a good movie, and I wanted to say that" Article: In a surprising move, renowned filmmaker Michael Moore has criticized a recent report done by Dr. Sanjay Gupta on CNN's Monday segment on Moore's acclaimed documentary "Sicko." Gupta's report, often known for its thoroughness and impartiality, questioned some of the numbers and solutions presented in Moore's movie about the US healthcare system. In response, Moore openly criticized Gupta's report.

Despite this, Gupta offered an olive branch, stating, "I thought it was a good movie, and I wanted to say that." In his report, Gupta had pointed out that some of the statistics presented by Moore may have been selectively chosen to support his point of view. However, Gupta also acknowledged that "Sicko" raised some legitimate concerns about the state of healthcare in America.

The exchange between the two media figures has sparked a broader discussion online about the role of objective journalism and how it should interact with the opinions of filmmakers such as Moore. Some critics have argued that it is essential for journalists to provide a balanced view of the facts, even if they support a filmmaker's overall message. Others have suggested that there is value in allowing filmmakers to present their arguments without necessarily challenging them at every turn.

Regardless of where one stands on this debate, it is clear that Gupta's report has not affected the popularity or impact of "Sicko" as a documentary. Through its powerful storytelling and emotional impact, it has continued to bring attention to the challenging realities faced by many Americans who struggle with healthcare costs and access.

Summary: Majority Leader says a number of Dems are "revisiting their own positions" Turkey is upset about World War I "genocide" resolution in Congress. House resolution calls killing of Armenians "genocide" Incirlik Air Base is key point for U.S. military supply of Iraq mission. Article: In a surprising turn of events, several Democrats have reportedly been reconsidering their positions on a controversial House resolution regarding the killing of Armenians during World War I. The resolution, which labels the event as "genocide," has drawn sharp criticisms from Turkey and has put a significant U.S. military base in the country in jeopardy.

According to the Majority Leader, a number of Democrats are "revisiting their own positions" on the matter, as tensions between the U.S. and Turkey mount. The resolution, which passed with an overwhelming majority in the House, has yet to be taken up by the Senate.

Turkey, a key ally of the U.S. in the Middle East, has been vocal in its condemnation of the resolution, calling it an attack on its sovereignty. The country has threatened to shut down the Incirlik Air Base, which is a crucial point for the U.S. military's supply of its Iraq mission.

The Incirlik Air Base has been in use by the U.S. military since the 1950s and has served as a key staging ground for operations across the Middle East. If Turkey follows through on its threat, it could significantly hamper the U.S.'s ability to carry out its mission in Iraq.

The resolution, which has been a long-standing issue for the U.S. government, has been a sensitive topic between the U.S. and Turkey. In the past, U.S. presidents have been reluctant to use the term genocide out of fear of damaging relations with Turkey.

Now, with tensions high and the threat of a key military base in jeopardy, all eyes are on the Senate as it decides whether or not to take up the controversial resolution.

Summary: Boy, 12, lost leg to car bombing in Iraq; cousin was killed by blast. He is now heading to the United States to get a prosthetic leg. Boy: "I want to ... meet this person that gave me my future back" Charity director says helping the boy makes her "cry with joy" Article: A 12-year-old boy from Iraq who lost his leg in a devastating car bombing is heading to the United States to get a prosthetic leg. The boy's cousin was killed by the blast that also left him severely injured. "I want to learn to walk again and meet this person that gave me my future back," said the boy.

The charity director responsible for helping the boy make the journey expressed deep emotions about the experience. "Helping this young boy makes me cry with joy," said the director.

The boy's journey has been planned for some time, with the charity working tirelessly to ensure all the necessary travel arrangements and medical consultations are in place. He is expected to undergo a fitting for his new prosthesis shortly after arriving in the United States.

The boy's story highlights the devastating impact of conflicts and acts of terror on innocent civilians, particularly children. Despite the tragic loss of his cousin and his own severe injuries, his determination to move forward with his life is both inspiring and humbling.

The charity responsible for helping the boy has received an outpouring of support from donors, supporters, and members of the public. Their work to provide practical and emotional support to innocent victims of conflict and terror is widely recognized and valued.

Summary: India elects first female president, official results show Saturday. Pratibha Patil's supporters are calling victory a boost for women's rights. Bitter election campaign was marked by scandal. 72-year-old Patil was the ruling coalition's nominee for mainly ceremonial post. Article: On Saturday, India made history by electing its first-ever female president, Pratibha Patil. Her victory is being hailed as a significant milestone for women's rights in the country.

Patil's supporters are overjoyed, seeing her election as a sign of progress in a society where women often face discrimination and inequality. Her win is particularly meaningful given that she will hold a mainly ceremonial post, symbolizing the growing power and influence of women in politics.

However, the election campaign leading up to Patil's victory was fraught with scandal and controversy. As the nominee of the ruling coalition, she faced fierce opposition from rival parties who hurled allegations of corruption and nepotism against her.

Despite the intense criticism, Patil weathered the storm and emerged victorious, winning the support of a majority of the country's lawmakers. At 72 years old, she brings a wealth of experience to the presidency and is seen as a highly respected figure in Indian politics.

Her triumph is a significant moment in a country that has traditionally been male-dominated. As India continues to modernize and move towards greater gender parity, many hope that Patil's election will inspire further progress and pave the way for more women to take on leadership roles in all areas of society.

Summary: San Diego mayor declares state of emergency; White House, governor offer aid. Officials were investigating the shifting earth in the area for weeks. Residents can return to 75 of the 111 evacuated homes Thursday, mayor says. "We watched the trees snapping and cracking," says one evacuated resident. Article: San Diego, California - The mayor of San Diego, Todd Gloria, has declared a state of emergency in response to the shifting earth in the area. The White House and Governor Gavin Newsom have offered aid to the affected residents.

Officials have been investigating the area for weeks after reports of the earth moving. On Wednesday, 111 homes were evacuated due to the danger of landslides.

Residents have been living in temporary accommodation since Wednesday. However, the mayor announced that 75 of the 111 evacuated homes are now safe to return to on Thursday.

Despite this, residents are still feeling the impact of the incident. One resident who was evacuated said, "we watched the trees snapping and cracking, it was really scary. We're thankful that we're okay, but it's still a traumatic experience."

The city is continuing to monitor the situation and assist affected residents. The cause of the shifting earth is still under investigation.

The White House has pledged its support to the city and its residents. President Joe Biden has been briefed on the situation and has offered any necessary Federal assistance to support the response effort.

Governor Newsom said he was "in constant contact" with the mayor's office and other local officials and urged residents to "remain vigilant and take any necessary precautions."

The situation in San Diego is ongoing, and residents are encouraged to follow the advice of local officials.

Summary: Chadian president wants journalists, flight crew released. Red Cross, UNICEF, UNHCR interview children that charity tried to fly out of Chad. Most are not from Sudan and have families, agencies say. Six members of Zoe's Ark, 11 others under arrest in Chad. Article: Chadian President Demands Release of Journalists and Flight Crew, Charity Officials Remain Under Arrest

The president of Chad, Idriss Deby, has demanded the release of four French journalists and three Spanish flight crew who were detained in the country last Thursday. They were reportedly investigating the activities of the French charity, Zoe's Ark, which was trying to fly 103 children out of the country without proper authorization. 

The charity claimed that the children were orphans from the war-torn region of Darfur in Sudan, but a joint mission by the Red Cross, UNICEF, and the UNHCR has found that most of them have families and are not from Darfur. The agencies are currently working to reunite the children with their families.

Meanwhile, six members of Zoe's Ark, including its president, Eric Breteau, and his partner, Emilie Lelouch, remain under arrest in Chad, along with 11 others, on charges of child abduction and fraud. 

The case has sparked outrage in France, with many people expressing shock and disbelief that a charity could act with such recklessness. The French foreign ministry has said that it is doing everything it can to secure the release of the journalists and flight crew.

The Chadian government has been equally firm in its response, with President Deby calling the actions of Zoe's Ark "unacceptable and criminal." 

The case is likely to remain in the headlines for some time as more details emerge about the charity's activities, and as the legal process unfolds. For now, however, the focus is on the children and their families, and on ensuring that they are reunited as quickly as possible.

Summary: Earth has warmed one degree in past 100 years. Majority of scientists say greenhouse gases are causing temperatures to rise. Some critics say planets often in periods of warming or cooling. Article: Earth's temperature has warmed by one degree over the past century, according to a report released by a global panel of scientists. The report indicates that there is a scientific consensus that greenhouse gas emissions are the primary cause of this increase, with the majority of researchers agreeing that human activity is responsible for the rapid warming trend.

While many are calling for urgent action to address climate change, some critics are questioning the science behind these findings. They point out that Earth has experienced periods of warming and cooling throughout its history, and that fluctuations in temperature may not necessarily be caused by human activities.

However, most scientists argue that the current rate of global warming is unprecedented in human history, and that we are already seeing the devastating impacts of a warming climate, including extreme weather events, rising sea levels, and loss of biodiversity.

The report makes it clear that urgent action is needed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow the rate of global warming. Governments, businesses, and individuals all have a role to play in reducing our carbon footprint, from investing in renewable energy to reducing waste and supporting sustainable agriculture.

As the planet continues to warm, the stakes are high. We must take decisive action now to protect our planet and ensure a habitable future for generations to come.

Summary: Ethiopian soldier dragged after battle with Islamic insurgents killed 19 people. The body was bound hand and foot with wire and wrapped in a sheet of plastic. Incident recalls 1993 dragging of U.S. soldier through streets of Mogadishu. Washington is concerned Somalia could turn into a safe haven for terrorists. Article: In a disturbing incident that harkens back to a tragic event from decades ago, an Ethiopian soldier was dragged after a battle with Islamic insurgents in Somalia. The soldier's brutal death resulted in the killing of 19 people and has raised concerns about the potential for Somalia to become a safe haven for terrorists.

The soldier's body was found bound hand and foot with wire and wrapped in a sheet of plastic. The incident recalls the horrific 1993 dragging of a U.S. soldier through the streets of Mogadishu, which was immortalized in the book and film "Black Hawk Down."

Washington is particularly concerned about the situation in Somalia given the ongoing threat of terrorism. The nation has long been a hotbed for insurgency and extremist groups, including al-Shabab, an al-Qaida-linked group that has targeted Western interests in East Africa.

The latest killings are a grim reminder of the ongoing violence and instability in the region, and underscore the need for continued efforts to promote peace and security in Somalia. With extremist groups continuing to operate with relative impunity in the country, there is an urgent need to address the underlying conflicts and grievances that fuel the insurgency and find a pathway towards a more peaceful and stable future.

Summary: Judge signs order to exhume the body of Drew Peterson's third wife. Peterson has said he believed his fourth wife left him for another man. Police: Case shifts from a missing persons search to a potential homicide. Friends and family: Stacy Peterson expressed concerns about her husband. Article: A bombshell development has emerged in the case involving the disappearance of Drew Peterson's fourth wife. The former Illinois police sergeant was convicted in 2012 for the murder of Kathleen Savio, his third wife. But now, as the investigation into his fourth wife Stacy Peterson's disappearance deepens, a judge has signed an order to exhume the body of Drew Peterson's third wife.

Peterson had long maintained that his fourth wife had left him for another man. But police say the case has now shifted from a missing persons search to a potential homicide investigation. Friends and family members of Stacy Peterson have also expressed their concerns about Drew, with some saying that she was afraid of him.

The decision to exhume Kathleen Savio's body could provide crucial evidence in the case. Although Peterson was convicted of her murder, the defense had argued that her death was accidental, the result of falling in her bathtub. But the condition of her body could provide forensic clues that would support or refute that theory.

The case has attracted national attention since Stacy Peterson's disappearance in 2007. Drew Peterson has been a controversial figure, with many accusing him of manipulating the justice system in order to avoid prosecution. The new development certainly raises the stakes in the investigation and could bring closure to the families of both of Peterson's former wives.

Summary: Julia Vakulenko has reached her first final on the WTA Tour at Bell Challenge. The Ukrainian third seed will face Lindsay Davenport after beating Julie Ditty. Former world No. 1 Davenport defeated Russian second seed Vera Zvonareva. Article: Julia Vakulenko to Face Lindsay Davenport in First Career WTA Tour Final

Julia Vakulenko of Ukraine has made history after reaching her first-ever final on the WTA Tour at the Bell Challenge in Canada. As the third seed at the tournament, Vakulenko defeated American player Julie Ditty in the semifinals in a hard-fought match that saw her victorious in straight sets.

The victory sees Vakulenko advance to the final where she will face the former world number one and eighth seed, Lindsay Davenport. Davenport had a tough path to the final after defeating the second-seeded Russian player, Vera Zvonareva, in another exciting semifinal match.

Vakulenko has been having a stellar run at the tournament with victories over Tatiana Perebiynis, Stephanie Dubois, and Laura Granville, among others. With her sights set on the title, she will have to rely on her mental and physical strength to defeat the experienced Davenport and claim her first WTA Tour crown.

The Bell Challenge, which has been running since 1993, is an annual women's professional tennis tournament played on indoor carpet courts in Quebec City, Canada. The tournament attracts some of the world's top-ranked players, as well as emerging talent such as Vakulenko.

Fans around the world will be eagerly anticipating the final, as two talented players battle it out for the coveted title. Will Vakulenko be able to overcome the experienced Davenport to clinch her first WTA Tour title, or will the American veteran show her class and come out on top? Tennis enthusiasts will have to wait and see.

Summary: President Musharraf orders troops to take a television station's equipment. Pakistani opposition leader Imran Khan says he's under house arrest. President Musharraf says his actions are for the good of the country. White House calls Musharraf's emergency declaration "disappointing" Article: In a move that has sparked uproar among opposition leaders and human rights activists, Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf has ordered military forces to seize the equipment of a television station in Islamabad. According to reports, the President wanted to prevent the station from broadcasting further criticism of his rule.

Opposition leader Imran Khan has said that he is under house arrest and has condemned the crackdown on the media. He argued that freedom of expression is crucial in a democracy and called for immediate restoration of rights of journalists and media personnel.

In response, President Musharraf defended his actions, stating that they were necessary to ensure stability and security in the country. He asserted that the media should not be allowed to incite violence and provoke unrest, which could threaten national security.

The emergency declaration has drawn criticism from around the world, with the White House calling it "disappointing." The US government has long considered Pakistan a key ally in the fight against terrorism, but this latest move is likely to strain relations between the two nations.

As the situation continues to develop, many are calling on the Pakistani government to uphold the principles of democracy and protect the rights of its citizens. Human rights groups have warned that any attempt to silence opposition voices and suppress dissent could lead to a serious erosion of democratic freedoms in the country.

Summary: Robert A. Singer is accused of e-mailing child porn to 12-year-old girl. 12-year-old girl was actually undercover New York City detective. Singer was identified in court document as National Children's Museum spokesman. Washington museum officials say they are "horrified" by the charges. Article: Robert A. Singer, who had been identified in court document as the National Children's Museum spokesman, has been accused of e-mailing child pornography to a 12-year-old girl. However, the "girl" in question was actually an undercover detective from New York City. Singer, 35, was arrested and charged with promoting and possessing a sexual performance by a child.

The National Children's Museum officials expressed their horror and shock at the charges against Singer. The museum released a statement saying that the allegations against Singer were "abhorrent" and that they have zero tolerance for such behavior. The museum has also confirmed that Singer had been placed on administrative leave pending the outcome of the investigation.

According to the police report, Singer had communicated with the undercover detective via e-mail over several weeks. During that time, he had sent her several sexually explicit messages and photos of children. Once the authorities were able to identify the location where the e-mails were being sent from, they executed a search warrant and found Singer in possession of child pornography.

Singer's defense attorney has not yet commented on the case. The preliminary hearing is scheduled for later this month, where the prosecutor plans on presenting significant evidence against Singer. If convicted of the charges, Singer could face up to 15 years in prison.

The National Children's Museum desires justice to be served in this matter, and expresses sincere apologies to those who have been affected. This situation highlights the importance of comprehensive background checks for all employees, especially those who work in close proximity to children.

Summary: Accused pedophile Chester Arthur Stiles gets additional charges. "I think he's a little out of it," his attorney says. Suspect's ex-girlfriend: "I've had my share of nightmares" Stiles, 37, arrested following a routine traffic stop. Article: The accused pedophile Chester Arthur Stiles has gotten additional charges added to the ones that landed him in jail in the first place. The 37-year-old was arrested following a routine traffic stop, but upon his detainment, authorities found that Stiles had been wanted for a series of sexual assault and child pornography charges. Now, with these additional charges, it seems that Stiles’ legal troubles are only going to get worse.

Despite the mounting evidence against him, Stiles’ attorney is still trying to defend his client’s actions. "I think he's a little out of it," the attorney said in a statement to the press. "He's just not all there."

Meanwhile, Stiles' ex-girlfriend, who asked not to be named, has expressed her shock over the allegations. "I've had my share of nightmares, but nothing like this," she said in an interview with local reporters.

For now, Stiles remains in custody, with the judge setting his bail at half a million dollars. Although his case is still ongoing, it is clear that the laundry list of charges against him is only growing, leaving many in the local community to wonder just how deep Stiles' alleged crimes may go.

Summary: South Africa lead New Zealand by 287 with 8 wickets standing in the 1st test. The Proteas reach 179-2 in their second innings after the Kiwis are 118 all out. South African paceman Dale Steyn takes a career-best 5-34. Article: In the first test match between South Africa and New Zealand, the Proteas have taken a commanding lead of 287 runs with only 8 wickets standing. After bowling out the Kiwis for a mere 118 runs, the South African team was able to reach 179-2 in their second innings.

The star of the show was South African paceman Dale Steyn, who took a career-best 5-34 in the Kiwis’ first innings. He was virtually unplayable, as the New Zealand batsmen struggled to cope with his pace and swing. Steyn’s spell included four wickets in a single over, which left the Kiwis stunned and reeling.

The Proteas’ batsmen, on the other hand, had no such problems as they were able to score runs at will. Opener Dean Elgar scored a brilliant century in the first innings, while Aiden Markram kept the scoreboard ticking with a half-century. In the second innings as well, Elgar and Markram started well and added a quickfire opening partnership.

The Kiwi bowlers tried their best to make a comeback, but the Proteas batsmen were too good for them. With a lead of 287, South Africa will now look to bat New Zealand out of the game and take a 1-0 lead in the three-match series.

Overall, it was a dominant display from the Proteas, who will be buoyed by their performance in the first test match. With Dale Steyn looking in ominous form and the batsmen firing on all cylinders, it will take a monumental effort from New Zealand to come back in this match.

Summary: Real Simple tips can add up to great summer. Best way to catch fireflies starts with easiest to catch. Tip on how not to look like a gladiator when wearing espadrilles. There is a graceful way to get in and out of a hammock. Article: Real Simple Tips Add Up to Great Summer Fun

As summer approaches, many are looking for ways to make the most out of the season. Thankfully, Real Simple has come to the rescue with a collection of simple yet effective tips to enhance any summer activity or outing.

For those looking to catch fireflies, the best tip comes from starting with the easiest ones to catch. While it may be tempting to aim for the elusive ones that are higher up, starting with easier targets will build confidence and lead to a more successful catch.

Wearing espadrilles can give anyone a taste of summer fashion, but it's important to avoid looking like a gladiator in the process. Real Simple suggests tucking in the laces and avoiding too many accessories to maintain a chic and effortless look.

Hammocks are a classic summer accessory, but nothing ruins the relaxation more than an awkward and clumsy attempt to get in and out. Luckily, Real Simple has a graceful solution - hold onto the fabric instead of the sides to maintain balance and control.

While each tip may seem small, they add up to create a memorable and enjoyable summer. With Real Simple's guidance, anyone can elevate their summer experiences with ease.

Summary: Jordan opens school doors to all Iraqi children, regardless of refugee status. Principal says her school is 20 percent Iraqi this year. Education minister: Iraqi kids will be incorporated into "mainstream" life. One student says he lost five family members in Iraq. Article: AMMAN, JORDAN - In a move aimed at providing equal education opportunities to all children, Jordan has opened its school doors to Iraqi children, irrespective of their refugee status. The move has been greeted with great appreciation by Iraqi families who have been displaced due to the ongoing war in their country.

The principal of a local school in Jordan, who wanted to remain anonymous, revealed that her school had enrolled around 20 percent of Iraqi children this year. She emphasized that the school was happy to accommodate all children who wished to learn and were in need of an education.

Jordan's Education Minister, Tarek Shawqi, has echoed the sentiments of the school principal, stating that the inclusion of the Iraqi children in the education system is a part of a broader effort aimed at incorporating them into mainstream life in Jordan.

One of the Iraqi students who is now attending the Jordanian school revealed that he had lost five family members in the ongoing conflict in his home country. However, he expressed gratitude for getting an opportunity to learn in a peaceful environment.

The move to open schools to Iraqi children will help to provide educational opportunities to thousands of children who have been forcefully uprooted from their homes in Iraq. The Jordanian government deserves credit for its efforts to support the refugees, who are in dire need of help during these difficult times.

Summary: President Bush nominated Mukasey to replace Alberto Gonzales. Mukasey is a former federal chief judge in New York. Some Democratic senators opposed nominee due to views on waterboarding. Human rights groups consider waterboarding a form of torture. Article: Washington D.C. - President George W. Bush has nominated former federal chief judge Michael Mukasey to replace Alberto Gonzales as the nation's top law enforcement official. Mukasey, a prominent New York judge, has been lauded for his fair and even-handed approach to the law. However, his nomination has not been without controversy.

Some Democratic senators have voiced their opposition to the nomination, citing Mukasey's views on waterboarding as the primary concern. Human rights groups have long considered waterboarding, a technique used to simulate drowning, to be a form of torture. Mukasey has declined to categorize the technique as torture, stating that "if it amounts to torture, then it is illegal," but stopping short of condemning the practice altogether.

The debate over waterboarding has been hotly contested in recent years, with the Bush administration denying that it constitutes torture and implementing the technique in the interrogation of suspected terrorists. However, the technique has been widely criticized by many quarters, including Congress and the United Nations.

Despite the opposition to Mukasey's nomination, many analysts believe that he will ultimately be confirmed as attorney general. Mukasey's long and distinguished career on the bench, coupled with his close ties to the Bush administration, are seen as strong factors in his favor.

If confirmed, Mukasey will face a range of challenges in his new position, including the ongoing war on terror, immigration reform, and the protection of civil liberties. With the debate over waterboarding expected to continue, it remains to be seen how Mukasey will approach this controversial issue, and whether he will be able to win over his critics.

Summary: Orme, Tennessee, has running water from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. Town's spring ran dry in midst of Southeast drought. Donated water is trucked in from Alabama. Completion of pipeline will solve problem for good. Article: Orme, Tennessee - As Southeast drought has continued to damage multiple communities, Orme is struggling to provide residents with sufficient water. The town's spring has run dry, and only has running water from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. each day. 

However, the town received a wonderful blessing when recently, donated water started being trucked from Alabama to meet the needs of the community. While the town is grateful for the assistance, officials are still working on finding a long-term solution to the problem. 

Thankfully, the solution may be nearing completion. A pipeline to bring water to Orme from nearby Bridgeport is currently being built, and it's anticipated to permanently resolve the water shortage. Officials are hoping to have the pipeline operational as soon as possible, with hopes that no further help will be needed from Alabama or other surrounding areas.

The people of Orme know they are not alone, and appreciate the support of those around them during this difficult time. They are optimistic that the pipeline will be completed soon, putting an end to the town's water shortage and ensuring clean water access for Orme residents for the years to come.

Summary: State-run news agency: China orders an investigation by quality control agencies. Children who swallow the beads can become comatose or have seizures. Toys are sold as Aqua Dots in the U.S., as Bindeez Beads in Australia. Three children were hospitalized in Australia after swallowing large quantities. Article: China has ordered an investigation into the quality control of toys sold under the names Aqua Dots in the United States and Bindeez Beads in Australia, according to a state-run news agency. The order came after reports emerged of three Australian children being hospitalized after swallowing large quantities of the toy beads.

The investigation was launched after concerns were raised about the safety of the beads, which can cause children to become comatose or experience seizures if swallowed. The beads are made with a chemical that can convert into a toxic drug when ingested.

The toys were produced in China and exported to several countries, including the United States and Australia. It is unclear how many of the toys have been sold and distributed worldwide.

Authorities in China have ordered quality control agencies to investigate the manufacturing process of the toys and to ensure that safety standards are being upheld. The move comes as China works to strengthen its reputation for producing safe and reliable products for export.

Parents and caregivers are being urged to be vigilant and to consider removing the toys from children's play areas. Manufacturers of the toys have not yet issued a recall.

This incident is not the first involving potentially dangerous toys from China. In 2007, a massive recall of toys and other products, including Aqua Dots, was carried out around the world due to concerns about lead paint and other hazards.

Summary: Congo rebels blame Rwandan Hutus for attack, report says. Internally displaced Congolese flee as rebels attack government troops. Torrential rain makes refugee movement difficult. U.N. refugee agency: Some 375,000 have been forced from homes in past year. Article: In yet another incident of violence in war-torn Congo, rebels have blamed Rwandan Hutus for an attack on government troops, according to a report by local media sources. The attack has led to the displacement of several internally displaced Congolese who had already been forced from their homes due to the ongoing turmoil in the region.

The refugees had attempted to flee to safer areas in the wake of the attack, but the torrential rain has made movement difficult, making their situation all the more precarious. The violence has been one of many instances of conflict that have ravaged the region in recent months, with rebels and government forces frequently engaging in violent confrontations.

According to the United Nations refugee agency, the past year has seen 375,000 people being displaced from their homes across Congo, making it one of the most extensive displacements in the history of the country. The humanitarian situation in the region remains dire, with both refugees and local populations struggling to survive amidst the chaos.

The Congolese government has been accused of failing to take adequate steps to address the humanitarian crisis, with the focus being primarily on military solutions to the conflict. The U.N. has called for a comprehensive approach that prioritizes the needs of civilian populations.

The situation in Congo remains highly volatile, with no end in sight to the conflict that has claimed countless lives and made refugees out of thousands of innocent civilians. It's essential that the international community come together to help those in need and put an end to the violence that continues to grip the region.

Summary: "Wine Library TV" Internet show has about 40,000 regular viewers. Show takes irreverent look at wine business. Wine consumption has risen in United States for last 15 years. Article: "Wine Library TV" Internet Show Gains Popularity Among Wine Enthusiasts in the USA

"Wine Library TV," an Internet show that takes an irreverent look at the wine business, has gained popularity among wine enthusiasts across the United States. The show, hosted by Gary Vaynerchuk, attracts around 40,000 regular viewers.

The show features Vaynerchuk's humorous and entertaining commentary as he reviews various wines, offering his opinion on their flavor and quality. Vaynerchuk's unique approach to wine reviewing has made "Wine Library TV" a hit among wine aficionados.

Wine consumption has been on the rise in the United States over the past 15 years, with many people looking to learn more about the world of wine. "Wine Library TV" has become a valuable resource for those looking to expand their knowledge and appreciation of wine.

Vaynerchuk's no-nonsense style has been a refreshing change from the often stuffy and elitist world of wine connoisseurs. His unique approach to wine reviewing has made the show a cult favorite among wine enthusiasts, with many tuning in regularly to get their dose of Vaynerchuk's humor and wit.

With the rising popularity of "Wine Library TV," Vaynerchuk has become a household name in the world of wine. His show has helped to demystify the world of wine and has made it accessible to a wider audience.

As wine consumption continues to rise in the United States, "Wine Library TV" is sure to remain a popular resource for wine enthusiasts across the country.

Summary: Survivors of Cyclone Sidr in Bangladesh waiting for aid to arrive. Red Crescent Society official says deaths could rise to 5,000-10,000. Bangladeshi president distributes aid; angry survivors go empty-handed. Thousands remain missing; estimated 280,000 homeless. Article: Survivors of Cyclone Sidr in Bangladesh are still struggling a week after the storm hit the country's southern coast. Aid is struggling to arrive in the storm-ravaged area, and survivors are becoming increasingly desperate.
